title: 109_hr3482
content: The Children's Act for Responsible Employment of 2005, also known as the CARE Act of 2005, includes a short title and a table of contents. SEC. 2 of the Children's Act for Responsible Employment of 2005 revises the age requirement for child agricultural employment and repeals the waiver provision for hand harvest laborers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to exempt employees under 16 years old working in agriculture on a family-owned farm from child labor laws. The waiver provision for hand harvest laborers is repealed. SEC. 3. INCREASED CIVIL PENALTIES FOR CHILD LABOR VIOLATIONS. Section 16(e) of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to increase civil penalties for violations related to serious work-related injuries or illnesses, with fines ranging from $500 to $100,000 depending on the severity and repetition of the violation. SEC. 4. Special criminal penalties for aggravated child labor violations include imprisonment for up to five years or a fine for violations resulting in death or disability of an employee under 18. SEC. 5. A new section requires reporting on work-related injuries to children. The Secretary will analyze data on children under 18 working in agriculture, focusing on serious work-related injuries, illnesses, and deaths. Sources include the Department of Labor, state agencies, and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. Definitions include "serious lost-time work-related injury" for employees under 18. The Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress summarizing data on child labor in agriculture, including serious work-related injuries and illnesses for employees under 18. The Secretary will report to Congress on child labor in agriculture, including potential violations of employing children under 18. SEC. 6. EMPLOYER REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include a new section on employer reporting requirements. Employers must report serious lost-time work-related injuries, illnesses, or deaths of employees under 18 years of age in agriculture to the Secretary within five days. The report should include employer and employee details, as well as information about the incident. Employers must report serious lost-time work-related injuries, illnesses, or deaths of employees under 18 years of age in agriculture to the Secretary within five days. The report should include details about the injury, illness, or death of the employee, and any other information required by the Secretary. Failure to report may result in a civil penalty of up to $7,000 per violation. The terms 'serious lost-time work-related injury' and 'serious lost-time work-related illness' are defined in section 12A. SEC. 7. ENFORCEMENT OF CHILD LABOR PROVISIONS. The Secretary of Labor will hire 100 additional inspectors to enforce child labor laws and increase the budget for prosecuting violations. SEC. 8. PESTICIDE-RELATED WORKER PROTECTION STANDARD. (a) The Secretary of Labor must incorporate the worker protection standard for workers exposed to pesticides into the child labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act within 180 days of this Act. Any revisions to this standard must also be included in these rules. (b) Civil penalties under the Fair Labor Standards Act will be reconciled with new subsections added to Section 16. The Fair Labor Standards Act, Section 16, is amended to allow the offsetting of civil penalties imposed by the Secretary and the Administrator of the EPA for violations related to worker protection standards under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act. The Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act allows the Secretary to offset civil penalties for violations involving the same conduct affecting child workers. SEC. 9. YOUTH ACTIVITIES FOR FARMWORKERS. The Secretary will allocate funds for youth activities for farmworkers under the Workforce Investment Act of 1996. SEC. 10. APPLICATION OF FAIR LABOR STANDARDS AMENDMENTS. The Secretary of Labor must issue final rules within 180 days of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments. Violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act after the rules take effect will be subject to the amendments. State laws providing greater protections for employees will not be preempted. Employer reporting requirements under section 12B of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply. The final rules under section 12B of the Fair Labor Standards Act will take effect when issued under subsection (a).
